abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Programmatic
            Fiscal Sustainability Development Policy Loan Project (FSDPL
            I) for Jamaica were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            coordination with other multilaterals and bilateral
            institutions enhances the impact of Bank operations. FSDPL I
            was part of a package of support for the Jamaica Debt
            Exchange (JDX) by International Financial Institutions
            (IFIs) and bilateral donors, and its impact was amplified by
            complementary programs by the International Monetary Fund
            (IMF) and the Inter-American Development Bank (IADB). Use of
            high level outcome indicators to measure progress can be
            problematic. Since this was an operation that was meant to
            enhance debt and fiscal sustainability, it made sense, a
            priori, to include quantitative measures such as the primary
            balance to gross domestic product (GDP) and debt to GDP. In
            hindsight, however, it was clear that these outcomes are
            well beyond the control of the Bank or the Government. The
            impact of the global crisis, the Supreme Court ruling on
            wages, and an early election on these indicators was
            something that was difficult to counter with the measures
            envisaged in the FSDPL series. The use of technical
            assistance and/or investment lending to bolster capacity can
            help achieve results on reforms. Including privatization of
            specific enterprises as an outcome indicator is problematic.
